message.raw:
Fix issue where servers would have console windows when they were supposed to be
started in the background.

Add '--daemon' arg to servers, otherwise they start with cmd consoles in
Windows even if their parent process does not have one. Call them with this
arg from labscript setup code that expects them to be daemons.
message.html:
Fix issue where servers would have console windows when they were supposed to be
started in the background.

Add '--daemon' arg to servers, otherwise they start with cmd consoles in
Windows even if their parent process does not have one. Call them with this
arg from labscript setup code that expects them to be daemons.

Default to using the curses interface of the remote process server,
since it is so nice and since there is no longer a downside since the log
is visible.

message.raw:
Remove the concept of binding on local interfaces only.
Now in zprocess, unless allow_insecure is True, connections to and messages from
external interfaces are disallowed and discarded respectively, rather than
rejecting insecure binds. This increases flexibility without sacrificing
security.
message.html:

Now in zprocess, unless allow_insecure is True, connections to and messages from
external interfaces are disallowed and discarded respectively, rather than
rejecting insecure binds. This increases flexibility without sacrificing
security.

message.raw:
Add wrappers around zprocess functionality configuring it according to labconfig

* Added ls_zprocess, which wraps zprocess classes with singletons and
  subclasses configured to use labconfig encryption settings, as well
  as zlock host and port settings, and zprocess.remote  port setting.

* Added zlock.py, zlog.py and remote.py, which can be used to start zlock,
  zlog and zprocess.remote servers according to labconfig settings. zlog should
  not normally be run manually.

* Modified setup_logging.py and h5_lock.py to make use of the wrapped classes.
  Note that once h5_lock is imported by an application, or once a logging handler
  is configured, the ProcessTree object created is set as the zprocess default
  process tree. This is backward compatibility for applications not using the
  wrapped classes. This does not mean encryption can be turned on and work
  everywhere, that will still be a backward incompatible jump. But it does mean
  that the settings are inherited by subprocesses using the now-deprecated
  Process() classes that do not specify a ProcessTree. So it provides backward
  compatibility for labscript suite programs whilst they remain unencrypted.

* Bump version so applications may make use of these classes and we can
  begin to move them to a state where encryption can be turned on.
  This should be in place before remote devices are implemented in BLACS.

These changes are intended to be backward compatible so far, but encryption
cannot be used until applications have their use of zprocess ported to use
these wrappers.
message.html:
Add wrappers around zprocess functionality configuring it according to labconfig

  • Added ls_zprocess, which wraps zprocess classes with singletons and
    subclasses configured to use labconfig encryption settings, as well
    as zlock host and port settings, and zprocess.remote port setting.

  • Added zlock.py, zlog.py and remote.py, which can be used to start zlock,
    zlog and zprocess.remote servers according to labconfig settings. zlog should
    not normally be run manually.

  • Modified setup_logging.py and h5_lock.py to make use of the wrapped classes.
    Note that once h5_lock is imported by an application, or once a logging handler
    is configured, the ProcessTree object created is set as the zprocess default
    process tree. This is backward compatibility for applications not using the
    wrapped classes. This does not mean encryption can be turned on and work
    everywhere, that will still be a backward incompatible jump. But it does mean
    that the settings are inherited by subprocesses using the now-deprecated
    Process() classes that do not specify a ProcessTree. So it provides backward
    compatibility for labscript suite programs whilst they remain unencrypted.

  • Bump version so applications may make use of these classes and we can
    begin to move them to a state where encryption can be turned on.
    This should be in place before remote devices are implemented in BLACS.

These changes are intended to be backward compatible so far, but encryption
cannot be used until applications have their use of zprocess ported to use
these wrappers.

These changes are intended to be backward compatible so far, but encryption

these wrappers.
summary.html:
Add wrappers around zprocess functionality configuring it according to labconfig

  • Added ls_zprocess, which wraps zprocess classes with singletons and
    subclasses configured to use labconfig encryption settings, as well
    as zlock host and port settings, and zprocess.remote port setting.

  • Added zlock.py, zlog.py and remote.py, which can be used to start zlock,
    zlog and zprocess.remote servers according to labconfig settings. zlog should

    Process() classes that do not specify a ProcessTree. So it provides backward

values.message:
Add wrappers around zprocess functionality configuring it according to labconfig

* Added ls_zprocess, which wraps zprocess classes with singletons and
  subclasses configured to use labconfig encryption settings, as well
  as zlock host and port settings, and zprocess.remote  port setting.

* Added zlock.py, zlog.py and remote.py, which can be used to start zlock,
  zlog and zprocess.remote servers according to labconfig settings. zlog should
  not normally be run manually.

* Modified setup_logging.py and h5_lock.py to make use of the wrapped classes.
  Note that once h5_lock is imported by an application, or once a logging handler
  is configured, the ProcessTree object created is set as the zprocess default
  process tree. This is backward compatibility for applications not using the
  wrapped classes. This does not mean encryption can be turned on and work
  everywhere, that will still be a backward incompatible jump. But it does mean
  that the settings are inherited by subprocesses using the now-deprecated
  Process() classes that do not specify a ProcessTree. So it provides backward
  compatibility for labscript suite programs whilst they remain unencrypted.

* Bump version so applications may make use of these classes and we can
  begin to move them to a state where encryption can be turned on.
  This should be in place before remote devices are implemented in BLACS.

These changes are intended to be backward compatible so far, but encryption
cannot be used until applications have their use of zprocess ported to use
these wrappers.

message.raw:
Keep a list of Python interpreters on Windows rather than hard-coding the most
recent, and try them all.

This way so long as the labscript suite is registered with *some* python interpreter,
the hook will work.

the hook will work.

message.raw:
Copy .sh or .bat file and hook .py file to the .hg directory to ensure
hook will always work. Exception is if the Python interpreter used to install
the hook disappears. In this case print a warning that the hook will need to
be reinstalled. Do not automatically install the hook when importing labscript_utils.

Plan is to make the installer do this when it 'registers' the install with a Python
environment.

message.raw:
Configure labscript suite repos to have an update hook that deletes .pyc files
and empty folders.

This configuration is checked and applied whenever labscript_utils is imported,
and runs when hg update is run.

This helps avoid trouble when leftover .pyc files from the wrong branch or
possibly even wrong Python version are importable even though their .py files
are gone.
message.html:

and empty folders.

and runs when hg update is run.

This helps avoid trouble when leftover .pyc files from the wrong branch or
possibly even wrong Python version are importable even though their .py files
are gone.

message.raw:
Add a function `get_unit_conversion_class(fullname)` to unitconversions module.
If a fully qualified class name is provided, this will import just the class
specified (even if it is not located within the unitconversions folder).

Otherwise, if just a class name is given without a full import path,
it falls back to importing everything to find the class of the given
name. This provides backward compatibility with shots compiled with versions
of labscript that save the class name only (i.e. the current version).

A custom `__all__` provides backward compatibility for versions of BLACS
(i.e. the current version) that import * from unitconversions. Submodules
are only imported en-masse if `__all__` is actually acessed, at which point
all the classes are imported and loaded into the globals dictionary (and their
names added to `__all__`).

This custom `__all__` even takes the bizarre step of adding items to the
`globals()` dictionary (and to `__all__`) with the fully qualified names, e.g.
'labscript_utils.unitconversions.submodule.SomeClass', usually disallowed
variable names in Python. This ensures that if an old version of BLACS
(i.e. the current version) imports * and inspects its `globals()` dict looking
for unit conversion classes, it will still find them, even if the shot file
the conversion class name is coming from was compiled with a newer version of
labscript that saves the full paths.

This change paves the way for:

* lascript to save fully qualified unit conversion class names, allowing
  unit conversion classes to be stored within userlib instead of labscript_utils.

* BLACS to improve performance by not importing all the classes en-masse.

whilst supporting full backward compatibility.

of labscript that save the class name only (i.e. the current version).

A custom __all__ provides backward compatibility for versions of BLACS
(i.e. the current version) that import * from unitconversions. Submodules
are only imported en-masse if __all__ is actually acessed, at which point
all the classes are imported and loaded into the globals dictionary (and their
names added to __all__).

This custom __all__ even takes the bizarre step of adding items to the
globals() dictionary (and to __all__) with the fully qualified names, e.g.
'labscript_utils.unitconversions.submodule.SomeClass', usually disallowed
variable names in Python. This ensures that if an old version of BLACS

  • lascript to save fully qualified unit conversion class names, allowing
    unit conversion classes to be stored within userlib instead of labscript_utils.

  • BLACS to improve performance by not importing all the classes en-masse.

whilst supporting full backward compatibility.

If a fully qualified class name is provided, this will import just the class
specified (even if it is not located within the unitconversions folder).

are only imported en-masse if `__all__` is actually acessed, at which point

message.raw:
Add dedent() function, which dedents and removes newlines from strings so
that you can more easily write multiline error message etc, such as:
```
def foo()
    msg = """There was an error, which we have written in code
        over multiple lines, but with indentation. This indentation
        and these line breaks should be ignored.

            1. But this extra indentation
            2. and line endings
            3. should be included verbatim

        and then this text at the original indentation level should be
        unwrapped again.
        """
    raise ValueError(dedent(msg))
```

This function is not quite the same as Python's textwrap.dedent, as this one
excludes the first line from the indentation calculation, removes newlines,
and includes lines with additional indentation verbatim. I've been using it to
make long error messages without having to manually join strings with '+' for
each line, which plays well with auto-wrapping text in text editors, e.g.
alt-Q in sublime text.

This function is not quite the same as Python's textwrap.dedent, as this one

alt-Q in sublime text.

values.message:
Add dedent() function, which dedents and removes newlines from strings so
that you can more easily write multiline error message etc, such as:
```
def foo()
    msg = """There was an error, which we have written in code
        over multiple lines, but with indentation. This indentation
        and these line breaks should be ignored.

            1. But this extra indentation
            2. and line endings
            3. should be included verbatim

        and then this text at the original indentation level should be
        unwrapped again.
        """
    raise ValueError(dedent(msg))
```

This function is not quite the same as Python's textwrap.dedent, as this one
excludes the first line from the indentation calculation, removes newlines,
and includes lines with additional indentation verbatim. I've been using it to
make long error messages without having to manually join strings with '+' for
each line, which plays well with auto-wrapping text in text editors, e.g.
alt-Q in sublime text.

message.raw:
Raise TypeError rather than silently converting non-string keys in JSON encoding.

Python's JSON encoder silently converts non-string dict keys to strings.
This can cause subtle bugs, and the user should be aware that they can only
store strings as keys. Conversion to strings should be done explicitly to
minimise surprise.

This can cause subtle bugs, and the user should be aware that they can only
store strings as keys. Conversion to strings should be done explicitly to
minimise surprise.

message.raw:
Make use of zlock's new readers-writers locks, if both client and server
are new enough to support them.
This allows multiple clients to acquire a lock on a file simultaneously, so long
as they have it open in read-only mode.

as they have it open in read-only mode.

message.raw:
Merged in pstarkey/linear_coil_driverpy-edited-online-with--1535436578217 (pull request #53)

Added check to kwarg in BiDirectionalCoilDriver to force it to an empty dictionary if no kwarg is specified when it is instantiated. This prevents exceptions occurring if you instantiate it with no kwarg.

Approved-by: Shaun Johnstone <shaun.johnstone@gmail.com>

message.raw:
Merged in pstarkey/linear_coil_driver (pull request #52)

Fixed bug in linear coil driver so that can handle both numpy arrays and single values as input when converting from base to amps (likely only used in analysis scripts)

Approved-by: Shaun Johnstone <shaun.johnstone@gmail.com>
Approved-by: Chris Billington <chrisjbillington@gmail.com>

message.raw:
Fix BLACS issue #22 by using the third-party concurrent_log_handler package
which resolves the race conditions in rotating logs used by multiple processes.

This introduces the module as a dependency, a separate pull request will
add it to the dependency list in the installer.
message.html:
Fix BLACS issue #22 by using the third-party concurrent_log_handler package
which resolves the race conditions in rotating logs used by multiple processes.

This introduces the module as a dependency, a separate pull request will
add it to the dependency list in the installer.

message.raw:
Do not check if string is QVariant if QVariant not present in qt library.
PySide2 does not have a QVariant type (and the check is not needed if using PySide2)
so this fixes an incompatibility with PySide2.
message.html:
Do not check if string is QVariant if QVariant not present in qt library.
PySide2 does not have a QVariant type (and the check is not needed if using PySide2)
so this fixes an incompatibility with PySide2.
